reviewText:
Played this game before it came to Steam and love it through and through!

There are visual novels with longer and deeper storylines, but Fading Heart managed to be more enjoyable than most of them; its characters are downright endearing, and the story is interesting with its share of twists and mysteries.

Among things that makes Fading Hearts favorably stand out among other VNs is that it gives you a lot of actual choice, rather then deciding the route for you based on often- unobvious dialogue choice. For instance, most VNs require the player to focus on pursuing specific girl, often at expense of being cold or downright rude to other girls to avoid getting unwanted “points” with them. Fading Hearts recognizes that being nice to a girl doesn’t mean you are romantically interested in her, and ultimately places decision of who to pursue into your hands. It encourages supporting all your friends regardless of your romantic interest, which I find a refreshing change from many other VNs.

Not to say that the plot can’t force something upon you, it sure can. But even when the choice is taken from you, it is the result of what you choose earlier – choose poorly!

To sum it up, I fully recommend Fading Hearts to everyone who enjoys VNs. And for people not familiar with the genre, I’d say it is a good choice of the first VN if they want to try them out.

reviewText:
Difficult to recommend for anyone other than big fans of the visual novel genre, and I deliberated on whether or not this was worth recommending. Leaning for no. If you're a fan of VNs (like me), this game will be worth your time; otherwise, I would look elsewhere.

The game promises you the ability to change the genre of the story, but the consequence of that is that too many different plot elements all seem to merge together into some kind of overwhelming mass, making the first playthrough very daunting. For all the directions the game can take, they don't see particularly refined. The result is a rather schizophrenic experience that can leave various threads unresolved, even with subsequent playthroughs. This game DOES improve with replays, and there are definitely elements of the story I really like (especially concerning Alex and Rina), but it requires significant investment to dig that up.

The stat-raising element of the game also disrupts the pacing of the game significantly. I found that I was grinding up knowledge or stats quite a bit in anticipation of something, anything to happen. The plot takes a backseat to however you intend to break it, and it doesn't really flow. This makes replays something of a chore, and the UI isn't well suited for that.

This is the first product of Sakura River and it offers a lot of potential for where they're going. I look forward to seeing more of what they produce in the future.

reviewText:
I so wanted to recommend this game, especially since I've only made it through one playthrough.  However, I can't work up the desire or motivation to playthrough again for any alternate endings.

All the components are there--and more.  Fading Hearts has the potential to be a really awesome game, given the variety of elements incorporated.  I just felt like there was a disconnect amongst everything, that gaming aspects and even characters were not delved into nearly enough before you reached an ending.  Why do you have to focus on one particular aspect at the expense of others?  Why are some aspects virtually worthless to develop?  Yes, I know there's supposed to be the whole replayability factor, but I find myself viewing a replay as just tedious.  I would have preferred a longer, more in-depth playthrough where all the different aspects (whether it's the rpg elements, the work, the training, the dating) were better connected and necessary.  I mean when only a handful of the manga are worth reading as far as character development. . .

For me, development and disconnect were also huge problems with the characters.  I want to be immersed in a world, invested in the charaters.  I ended my first playthrough not even really caring or even knowing much of anything about the Ryou.  All the rest of the supporting cast just seemed like sidenotes on repeat.  I don't know if it's this way with every playthrough, but rather than further developing characters, conversations just kept rehashing the same things.  I learned barely anything about anyone.  In fact, I probably knew as much about Tracy, the maid at the Cosplay restaurant, as I did about the more significant characters.

That development and disconnect issue carried over to the story itself.  Storylines that seemed significant at the beginning would just fizzle and disappear.  Then bam!  Here's a new shocking revelation--but there's virtually no explanation to the what, when, why, where, how questions.  But lets throw in some manga that's supposed to somehow be connected with no explanation of how it is connected, and hey, the future you (who we also have no clue as to why/what) will have a few conversations with you and disappear.

Some of the other issues are related to style.  Too many typos for a professional game.  Some odd wording/odd writing.  And the black screens.  Every time you read manga, the story displays itself as weird, stencilled script across a plain, black backdrop.  And there's a lot of manga you can read.  I won't even get into the manga writing, but how can you have text only manga?

So basically, when a major character apparently is killed off, and you just think huh" and "oh well

reviewText:
Much as it pains me, I can't give this game a good review.  It is nice to see games in this style being sold in Western markets, but regrettably this is not a particularly good example of the genre.  The story and characters are engaging, and have some depth, although the writing is mediocre (a real problem when the entirety of the game is read off the screen).

The real killer, however, is that the game is very poorly coded -- important events happen off-screen, without the player's involvement; interactions with characters reference events you have not experienced; and endings occur regardless of their triggers being hit (or not hit, as the case may be).

This game has a great concept, but its execution falls terribly short of the mark.  I wouldn't expect these errors in a free title, let alone a $15 game.  I do look forward to seeing future work from Sakura River -- possibly even a complete version of this title -- but I can't recommend this game to anyone but serious visual novel junkies looking for a fix, and even they are likely to be disappointed.

reviewText:
I can't recommend this game because it doesn't live up to what is promised.

The game bases itself on two premises:

1. Don't trust anything any character says, everyone lies at some point.
2. You can change the genre of the game by your own choices.

It fails on the first one because the game's central plot-driving story element is something you, the Main Character, are told about but never directly see. You're supposed to accept it unreflectively as the main premise of the entire story. This contradicts the emphasis on not believing everything the other characters say.

It fails on the second in that the non-dating sim elements of stat management and RPG battles feel tacked on and ultimately unnecessary. They're pointless at best, and repetitive at worst.

Fading Hearts is just too ambitious. It tries to do too much, and what is there is not well executed. It just comes off as lacking in focus. It's not completely without merit, but I can't recommend buying it. Nor do I think people who skip the game will really miss out, even if they're fans of the genre.

reviewText:
This game tries to do too much and ends up being a hot mess. There also seems to be a lot of bugs, glitches, and confusion about how to actually complete the damn thing.

They've added stat building elements, magic and combat (all RPG elements) into a game that also tries desperately to be a dating sim and visual novel. Very difficult to micro manage things and get what needs to be done accomplished. It was okay my first time through just focusing on the story and on which girl I'd rather date, but after I tried to go for all the endings and get into the complexity of the game, that's when it got frustrating. Balancing working, reading, training, relaxing, dating, socializing.. it's just too much.

Nobody can seem to agree on how to reach certain endings or get certain achievements. The newer version of the game didn't seem to fix these issues either. You can be on multiple ending tracks at once, and some endings completely contradict one another.. which is insanely frustrating. This game is riddled with all sorts of inconsistances and it makes me just not want to go through the effort of TRYING to finish it.

The front page advertises about one of the unique features being that characters can lie to you and that it's supposed to add some sort of mystique to the game and somehow be game changing. This is not the case at all. It feels nothing like that. I've played several times, picking each dialogue option to see the differences (if any), and really.. there are none.

I've played many a visual novel and this one just doesn't have a lot of characteristics that make a good one. The story is interesting, but nothing special. Your two love interests aren't all that interesting in the slighest. Choices seem to matter very little. Endings do not have a clear cut set of directions to follow in order to achieve them. Music is acceptable. I just can't really justify recommending this game for all of these reasons.

The devs really should have decided whether they wanted this game to be an RPG, a dating sim or a visual novel.. but not a bad combination of all three.

The pitch behind this game really cheapens the experience. I picked it up expecting a weirdo multigenre choose your own adventure story, but was instead treated to an unimaginative, honest-but-half-♥♥♥♥♥ attempt at, uh, something. My biggest complaint about the game is the writing. It's very, very bad. So bad, in fact, that I thought the game was a weird meta joke for an hour or so because the primary mechanic behind the 'combat' in the game involves learning magic powers from manga.

Also, you're a high school student whose parents have died, but luckily you're a genius programmer who has to make tough, decisions between coding for an indy game that doesn't pay very well or collapsing the world economy by not helping an IT worker. It's really bananas and I'd definitely click the reccomend button if this costed a dollar and didn't describe itself as a game that adapts itself to your decisions.

Here's a non-spoilery description of what your decisions affect: One of two of the anime high school girls will kiss you. One of the anime girls has an abusive boyfriend and you spend the first half of the game trying to figure out a way to get her to love you instead. The other girl is in love with you but to understand why she can't love you now you have to go fight monsters in the forest.

This game is terrible in a cool way, because it's sort of a sublime interpretation of what it is. It's aggressively dumb, but in a way that you can almost see every hilarious piece of the author's inadvertent self-awareness puzzle.

Buy this game if you want to laugh or to break up an anime girl from her abusive boyfriend by making decisions like talking to her about it or passive aggressively not talking to her about it while getting dating tips from your asexual otaku love-sensei.

For a game with 10 endings, the game's length and replay value aren't much. That is unless you are like me and squeeze every last bit of a game's 'valued' cost in order to get back its moneys worth.

Most of the events are predetermined and are based on the limited selection of options made by everyday decisions. Rather, the interactions are quite bland at best and the action & adventure aspect drastically dulls after the tenth battle of the same-looking monster.

In conclusion, if you're looking for an extremely cheap-thrilled visual novel worth 5-10 hours of your time (possibly less), this may be your game. Just know that the story length is very short, and the story itself isn't what you'd call pulitzer prize-winning material. If you do decide to buy the game, get ready as you'll probably be spending more time pressing the skip button and reading white words off a black screen, than anything else.

Worth the $15? I think not.

reviewText:
Fading Hearts is a highly interactive visual novel. While others engross you in a linear story, this game takes the 'well, it's shorter, but there are multiple endings' route. There are a couple things that I like and dislike about the game.

- It has a shallow battle system, which makes it feel like Persona at times. I personally think Persona gets way more credit than it deserves nowadays, but whatever. You can do things outside of battle to prepare yourself. Obviously this isn't the main dra of the game, and it's not that deep.
- The endgame is way too sparse compared to the rest of the game. You'll go a week or two with rarely any scenes, and you'll start to wonder if the game broke or something. On the two playthroughs I've had, this has been a problem with both. I have heard that aspects of the game are randomized, so it may or may not be a serious problem. Maybe I was just really unlucky.
- You get the sense that the developers quit early on this one. Not just because of the above, but you're marching along, thinking the story has a lot more life in it, and suddenly everything gets resolved in a series of events in a day or two. It just... ends. Abruptly.
- I see people complaining of the writing, both the content and the grammar/spelling. I wonder if were playing the same game. I remember no grammar/spelling errors, and I don't have serious problems with the content. It is quite a mishmash of ideas, though, veering closely to the otaku. And some of them are just plain stupid or cliche. But largely, it's passable.
- The developer makes too big a deal of everyone lying to you at some point. Yeah, everyone's keeping secrets... but that's par for the course in anime, really. It would have been more significant in my opinion if you were able to guess what these lies were before their reveals, but the twists are so far out there that you don't really get that chance.
- The advertised genre changes have a bit more meat to them. Depending on what you want to do, you can either discover the core of the story (going into supernatural elements), or not bother to discover the character's true intentions and treat this as a life sim.

I see this as $15 in the store now. Please wait until this is on sale. I think it's enjoyable, but not quite worth that price. There's a bunch of unused potential in the life sim part of this game, and I would pay attention to a spiritual successor.

reviewText:
Fading Hearts is not one of those games which will really win an award for spelling, nor will its story win an Oscar by any means. Fading Hearts as a VN game is confident, but that comes with some spelling errors. So if you’re a grammar N…Z or an English teacher, it’s not advisable to pickup and play this game. It could possibly drive you insane by the spelling mistakes in this game.

Also if by chance you’re picky on fictional settings and places not fitting in the logic of the real world then don’t pick this game up. But if you’re old enough to remember the ridiculous plots and plot holes of older Japanese VN games from the 80’s. Then you might have an idea what to expect as a back story plays out. In Fading Hearts Y2K led to a disaster which only affected one small nation in the whole world. That small nation is where our main catalog of characters in this game live. This leaves our main protagonist and his friends without parents because of the disaster which had befallen the small country of Sorayama.  Personally, I had to stop playing for a bit because I was laughing for a while after reading it.  But after getting my composure back I found out that I enjoyed Fading Hearts as a whole game.

With all that said, technically the game does everything VN games have done in the past and doesn’t really break that mold. That is not really a bad thing as VN games were always about how you discovered the world around you, but also the people you interacted with. That in itself, is what Fading Hearts does right, it gives you the ability to choose how you want to pursue your relationship with those characters’. As well as how your choices will affect the final ending of the game itself. So if you’re a relaxed person whom happens not to get too stuck up on a few spelling errors and an off the wall notion of the world Ryou lives in, give this game at least a shot.

reviewText:
Fading Hearts is not one of those games which will really win an award for spelling, nor will its story win an Oscar by any means. Fading Hearts as a VN game is confident, but that comes with some spelling errors. So if you’re a grammar N…Z or an English teacher, it’s not advisable to pickup and play this game. It could possibly drive you insane by the spelling mistakes in this game.

Also if by chance you’re picky on fictional settings and places not fitting in the logic of the real world then don’t pick this game up. But if you’re old enough to remember the ridiculous plots and plot holes of older Japanese VN games from the 80’s. Then you might have an idea what to expect as a back story plays out. In Fading Hearts Y2K led to a disaster which only affected one small nation in the whole world. That small nation is where our main catalog of characters in this game live. This leaves our main protagonist and his friends without parents because of the disaster which had befallen the small country of Sorayama.  Personally, I had to stop playing for a bit because I was laughing for a while after reading it.  But after getting my composure back I found out that I enjoyed Fading Hearts as a whole game.

With all that said, technically the game does everything VN games have done in the past and doesn’t really break that mold. That is not really a bad thing as VN games were always about how you discovered the world around you, but also the people you interacted with. That in itself, is what Fading Hearts does right, it gives you the ability to choose how you want to pursue your relationship with those characters’. As well as how your choices will affect the final ending of the game itself. So if you’re a relaxed person whom happens not to get too stuck up on a few spelling errors and an off the wall notion of the world Ryou lives in, give this game at least a shot.
